thread.title: A look inside Universal's Halloween Horror Nights houses for 2015
thread.title_full: A look inside Universal's Halloween Horror Nights houses for 2015

author: Dewayne Bevil
title: A look inside Universal's Halloween Horror Nights houses for 2015
text:
Orlando Sentinel dbevil​@tribune.com themeparks RT @TheDailyDisney: Disney Dining Buddy shuts down, says #Disney requested him to do so http://t.co/GclnMVyYOe http://t.co/0YKuKfb90Y Universal marks 25th Halloween Horror Nights 
It's the silver anniversary for Universal's Halloween Horror Nights, and that's appropriate because the event has been giving guests gray hairs for much of that time. 
It's the silver anniversary for Universal's Halloween Horror Nights, and that's appropriate because the event has been giving guests gray hairs for much of that time. Universal's haunted houses are ghosts of HHN past – in a good way 
Halloween Horror Nights is like going to a Universal High School reunion this year. Everything is kind of familiar, if twisted, ugly at times, full of screams and bad dreams. It can be bloody terrifying — and good, clean fun. And there's talk of the good ol' days. 
This year's event is the 25th one for Universal Orlando, which took old themes and smashed them into new ones while reviving key characters throughout the theme park. 
One prime example is Jack Presents 25 Years of Monsters and Mayhem, one of the record-high nine haunted houses. Visitors first see an entrance emblazoned with a bright, giant version of Jack the Clown's head, flanked by posters of icons of past years, such as the Director, the Storyteller and even young Cindy. Caption Halloween Horror Nights: Freddy vs. Jason Universal Orlando 
Freddy Kruger lurks around many corners inside the Freddy vs. Jason house at Universal's Halloween Horror Nights. 
Freddy Kruger lurks around many corners inside the Freddy vs. Jason house at Universal's Halloween Horror Nights. (Universal Orlando) Caption Halloween Horror Nights 25 Matt Mauney, Orlando Sentinel See more galleries 
Inside the winding way of this house —the longest in HHN history — are dozens of nightmarish characters from the past. We walked by Pumpkinheads, vicious bears, Frankenstein and friends plus scary clowns, including multiple incarnations of Jack. Although I've been to less than half of the Horror Nights, it was a stroll down memory lane. 
You might consider Jack Presents as a "greatest hits" package, but it also could be a strong introduction for HHN newbies. They wouldn't be distracted by trying to follow a storyline from a horror movie or the backstory of one of Universal's original tales. The house has a top-notch professional look, strong special effects and an army of scareactors lurking and lurching.
